name: TheAtlantic
text: On Saturday, the boy band BTS revealed a $1 million donation to Black Lives Matter. @kait_tiffany on how the organizing efforts of K-pop fandoms helped pave the way for these groups to show support: https://t.co/hFGfpINWoB

name: TheAtlantic
text: In quarantine, @amandamull writes, clutter is, in a thousand unexpected ways, a savior. https://t.co/dmAbJC5ImU

name: TheAtlantic
text: "We are now seeing America becoming better than it was," @KoriSchake writes. "This churning, disputatious, and even sometimes violent dynamic is what social change in America looks like." https://t.co/WJNDF25G4a

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Once the country has an improved idea about what policing is for, then begins the process of developing evidence-informed policies and practices to carry out that vision," @mearest and Tom R. Tyler write: https://t.co/QoiV0ZUCn2

name: TheAtlantic
text: "The irony of training at bases named for those who took up arms against the United States, and for the right to enslave others, is inescapable to anyone paying attention. Now, belatedly, is the moment for us to pay such attention," David Petraeus writes: https://t.co/VeZArWdgin

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Living a black life in Minneapolis means sitting in disparity between your good-natured neighbors and a system of structural racism and disenfranchisement enforced through policy, white silence, and police violence," @JustinNXT writes: https://t.co/CI12tOtUiM

name: TheAtlantic
text: Films like "Do the Right Thing" and "The Spook Who Sat by the Door" frame urban uprisings as just actions against brutality and as catalysts for change. @samshepPhD on movies about American protest: https://t.co/wDok0aZazo
